content.description:
Tiger King is a totally classic, Yosemite-esque, SPLITTER offwidth on beautiful black and white streaked granite. It is slightly overhanging and cruxy at the bottom to a perfect vertical splitter finish. This is the most splitter offwidth I am aware of in the South Platte and definitely one of the best (although I might be biased).

You can toprope this by climbing up the backside.
content.protection: 1-2 #6 BD and 1-2 VG 9, Big Bro #3 (a Big Bro actually works really well in this one) or #7 BD, bolts up top. If toproping, it is nice to have a directional, since the anchors are set a bit far back.
content.location: This is the rightmost route at the area and also the first one you will come across.

content.description: Hey, all you cool cats and kittens, put on your favorite leopard/tiger/cheetah print clothes, and enjoy this fun, slippery chimney that leads into a nice lieback flake.
content.protection: A single or double rack depending on comfort level, 3 bolts in the chimney, and a 2 bolt anchor up top.
content.location:
It is about 50 yards to the left of

Tiger King

.

content.description: This climbs a steep slab in an obtuse dihedral. It needs some cleaning between the 1st and 2nd bolts. Almost all the moves have been done just not linked, and I'm not a 12+ slab/sport climber in the slightest, so I'm not stoked on finishing it. This has really cool movement, but it is super techy. It will be a great route when it cleans up.
content.protection: Bolts. The route needs more bolts to be safe.

content.description:
Triple cracks converge into a nice but currently dirty dihedral.

This route can be done at least two ways that I know of. Both ways have the same start, which is a right-angling finger crack.

1) The obvious way is to go up into the chimney. At the wide pod, you can either take this way, or stem across and climb the other crack. Either way, you end up going through a tight squeeze. Once out of the squeeze, continue up the nice but dirty hand crack dihedral to the anchors.

2) If the squeeze scares you, from the finger crack, make a step across and over onto the other side of the leaning block. This way is more strenuous (maybe 5.10?) but saves you from going through the squeeze. After negotiating the overhang, continue up easier ground to a ledge, and from here finish on the same hand crack dihedral.

This one will be much better when the top half cleans up. As it currently is, it is still a fun and unique route, especially if you take the first variation.
content.protection: Cams 0.5 to #4, you can take some bigger cams if you really want, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This ascends the first crack left of "

That B*tch Carole Baskin

". Simply walk through the chimney or walk around the big boulder, and look up.

content.description:
The only reason to do this route is to set up a TR on

Tiger King

. Climb the offwidth and the crawl through the hole filled with a thorn bush, poop, and kitty litter.
content.protection: If you need gear, a #6 and a VG 9 will fit.
content.location:
It is on the backside of

Tiger King

.

content.description:
Here, Kitty Kitty is a classic country song by Joe Exotic detailing the murder of Carole Baskin's husband. In the song, Joe describes how she fed her husband to the tigers....

Here, Kitty Kitty is also a classic, splitter offwidth roof. To get to the crack itself, scramble into the cave to the left of the climb, and from a boulder, step across onto a small ledge, and grab the edge of the crack.... Figuring out how to get into the crack is part of the fun. The difficulties aren't over once you turn the roof, as you still have a steep, flaring, and overhanging crack to negotiate. After that, it's a glorious offwidth grovel to the top.

The first gear placement in the roof is blind, and you are about 20 feet off the ground at that point, so have your spotter double check your first piece from the ground before you invert into the crack. Alternatively, if you are too short or a scaredy-cat, you can lower off the anchors at the top and place your first piece (short people may have to jump to get the lip grab). This doesn't make the route any less difficult.

I didn't think about the grade too much on this one, it certainly isn't the hardest offwidth roof out there (using Crumbling Reality as a benchmark for the upper end of S. Platte offwidths, this one feels easier), but this one you are pretty much climbing above a series of waterfalls, so that's pretty unique and cool.

This gets afternoon shade in the summer.
content.protection:
BD #3-#7.... You can place a hand-size piece behind the flake inside the roof. It seemed 50% solid to me but I will try to remove it next time I'm up there. There are bolted anchors up top.

Be mindful of your rope, as you can get a nasty core shot on this route if you arent careful
content.location:
It is left of "

Carole Baskin Killed Her Husband

" under a huge roof.
